title: How Auditory Processing Deficits Can Interfere with a College Studentâ€™s Success in School and Work
chief_complaint: I have trouble following what teachers are saying and following social conversations. I also have a hard time tolerating loud noises like sirens, fire alarms, people yelling, and noisy places like malls.

problem_summary.course: Persistent; academic struggles in high school and college; difficulty maintaining employment due to listening issues.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Anxiety, emotional reactions to loud sounds, confusion in noise, inability to follow instructions.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Dropped out of community college; quit two retail jobs (grocery and department store) due to errors and noise intolerance.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking a comprehensive evaluation to understand why she is struggling despite previous normal hearing tests.

history.present_illness: Patient reports inability to follow verbal instructions and social conversations. She experiences significant distress and negative behavioral reactions (flinching, grimacing) to loud sounds.
history.otologic_history: Evaluated twice by school audiologist; results were normal hearing. No history of ear infections mentioned.
history.noise_exposure_history: Not significant, but reports intolerance to everyday environmental noises.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with anxiety disorder as an adolescent. Received remedial educational services and IEP (extended time, note taker).
history.prior_management: Previous audiologic evaluations ruled out peripheral hearing loss. Accommodations in school included note takers and extended test time.
history.patient_goals: Determine the cause of listening difficulties and sound intolerance.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Hearing within normal limits at 250 to 8,000 Hz bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal Speech Recognition Thresholds (SRT) and Word Recognition Scores (WRS) in quiet.

tests.name: Immittance audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal ear canal volume, middle ear pressure, and static compliance. Ipsilateral acoustic reflexes normal 500-4000 Hz.

tests.name: Auditory Hypersensitivity Assessment
tests.key_findings: Significant hypersensitivity. Tolerance thresholds were considerably lower than normal (90 dB HL). Negative reactions included flinching and grimacing.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: Performance within normal limits for W-22 in noise and SCAN-3A Auditory Figure-Ground.

tests.name: Auditory Temporal Processing
tests.key_findings: Normal temporal processing abilities on both Time Compressed Sentences and Pitch Pattern Sequence tests.

tests.name: Auditory Phonological Processing
tests.key_findings: Normal phonological processing on Phonemic Synthesis and Filtered Words tests.

tests.name: Dichotic Listening (Integration)
tests.key_findings: Significant deficits in auditory integration. Abnormal performance on Competing Words (Free and Directed Recall) and Staggered Spondaic Word (SSW) test. Competing Sentences (separation task) was normal.

overall_audiologic_summary: Peripheral hearing sensitivity is within normal limits bilaterally with excellent word recognition in quiet and normal speech-in-noise performance. However, central auditory processing evaluation reveals significant deficits in two specific areas: Auditory Hypersensitivity (tolerance levels 65-70 dB HL) and Auditory Integration (dichotic listening deficits on SSW and Competing Words). Temporal and phonological processing are intact.
counseling_points: Your standard hearing test is normal, meaning your ears detect sound perfectly well.

The difficulties you experience are due to Auditory Processing Disorder (APD), specifically problems with 'Auditory Integration' (how your brain combines information from both ears) and 'Auditory Hypersensitivity' (reduced tolerance to loud sounds).
Your intolerance to noise is real; sounds that are comfortable for others (above 65-70 dB) cause you physical or emotional distress.
The trouble you had in retail jobs and school stems from these processing issues, not a lack of intelligence or effort.
notes_for_actor: Portray a young adult who is anxious and frustrated by previous 'normal' hearing test results despite genuine struggles.
React visibly if loud sounds are mentioned or presented; you find them physically uncomfortable.
Emphasize that you can 'hear' people, but you get confused when there is a lot going on or when instructions are complex.
